topics.title: Deterministic to probabilistic marketing measurement shift
topics.summary: Austin explains how the post-IDFA era ended deterministic matching, forcing marketers to make spend decisions with probabilistic data and modeling/extrapolation approaches.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Austin Hay, his MarTech credentials, and what the episode will cover (definitions, org fit, hiring, tools, frameworks).

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for OneSchema (CSV importing) and Mixpanel (product analytics and attribution).

topics.title: What MarTech is and what it does
topics.summary: Austin defines MarTech as a cross-functional discipline at the intersection of product, growth, engineering, and marketing—like a PM for systems/platforms spanning third-party and first-party tooling.

topics.title: MarTech vs growth roles and when it emerges
topics.summary: They discuss how MarTech overlaps with growth at small companies, but becomes a distinct centralized ownership function as tool/data complexity grows—often around 100–150 employees.

topics.title: Signals you need a MarTech hire
topics.summary: Austin describes common pain points: overwhelmed tool owners, unclear data flows/schemas, inability to safely change systems, plus the unsexy but high-leverage work of contracts, cost scaling, and liability.

topics.title: Where MarTech should sit in the org
topics.summary: Austin outlines placement tradeoffs by B2C vs B2B and centralized vs decentralized models, emphasizing stakeholder alignment, resource allocation, and that there’s no single right answer—especially in B2B/B2B2C.

topics.title: IC nature of MarTech and cross-functional influence
topics.summary: Austin explains MarTech leaders remain hands-on experts in tools/systems while coordinating across teams; success depends more on lateral/upward management and persuasion than headcount managed.

topics.title: Day-to-day MarTech work and future-proofing systems
topics.summary: They cover operational responsibilities (permissions, governance, automation) and strategic work (roadmaps, financial models, gradual transformations), stressing balancing near-term speed with long-term stewardship.

topics.title: Supporting paid growth and funnel data activation
topics.summary: Austin describes partnering with paid acquisition teams rather than running campaigns, including advanced setups like sending downstream opportunity/value signals back to ad networks for better optimization.

topics.title: How MarTech should be goaled and measured
topics.summary: They discuss tying MarTech goals to growth/CAC outcomes while also tracking internal efficiency—especially controlling tooling costs per user/seat and executing major platform migrations (e.g., email tooling).

topics.title: Recommended B2C stack evolution: CDPs to reverse ETL
topics.summary: Austin explains the classic CDP-centered B2C stack (2017–2020) and the shift toward warehouse-first architectures with reverse ETL, highlighting the need for clear rules on where/how data should move.

topics.title: B2B and B2B2C stack complexity and CRM interplay
topics.summary: Austin contrasts Salesforce-centric B2B stacks with newer B2B2C complexity, focusing on identity/entity mapping (user-to-company) and the challenges of running multiple CRMs like HubSpot plus Salesforce.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Brave Search API, positioning it as an independent search index for search/AI apps with fresh web-scale data and lower costs.

topics.title: Attribution approaches: MMM vs MTA foundations
topics.summary: Austin frames MMM (marketing mix modeling) and MTA (multi-touch attribution) as downstream of data collection quality, explaining how MarTech underpins attribution by defining user/event data pipelines and future-proofing measurement.
